Risk factors

The risk of developing deep venous thrombosis is increased by:

  • Immobility
    • Pregnancy/postpartum period;
    • Post-surgery;
    • Use of an orthopedic cast;
    • Long travel times;
  • Smoking;
  • Being overweight;
  • A history of deep venous thrombosis in the family;
  • Medicines: contraceptives;
  • Pregnancy: due to hormonal changes;
  • Inheriting a blood-clotting disorder: increases the chance of clotting.

The more risk factors the patient has, the higher the risk of deep venous thrombosis. However, deep venous thrombosis is also seen in patients without risk factors.
